docs.lead_paragraph: Gabriel and I are sitting in her Harlem apartment, which smells faintly of incense. The cat is lurking behind the sofa. I am asking her about a woman she used to date, and whether it bothered Gabriel that the woman thought of herself, then and still, as straight. ''I'm not a future tripper,'' Gabriel says. ''I can't look beyond what happens at the moment. At the moment, we were in it. Then we weren't.'' She is relaxed, thoughtful -- flirty or inwardly amused, I'm not sure which. Once an avid raver, Gabriel, a small African-American woman who still wears an open loop of gold through her nasal septum, now works in public-health research at a major university. She's light on her feet, like a dancer. I ask her if she sees herself as falling at some particular point on a continuum of sexual identity, and she smiles. ''When I'm on the street, it's whatever turns my head,'' she replies. ''I'm a big flirt. Continuum? I don't have one. And when I'm getting down, I'm at the extreme end.'' She laughs. She tries to explain. ''All of the experiences I've had are part of my identity -- if you took a part of those experiences away, you'd take away a part of my identity.''
docs.abstract: Stacey D'Erasmo article on love in 21st century focuses on whether sexuality identity--gay, straight or bisexual--has outlived its usefulness; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Testing a suspicious powder for anthrax spores can be quick and inexpensive or slow and costly, experts said yesterday. And mistakes can be frequent, unless investigators take care and perform cross-checks. The instruments used for testing range widely, from hand-held detectors that cost $20 and give results in a few minutes to laboratory suites full of gear that must run for days to achieve certitude.

headline.main: Most Precise Tests for Anthrax Take Time, Care and Money
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: FINDING THE BACTERIA

docs.lead_paragraph: The pregnancy rate for teenagers fell for the fifth consecutive year last year, following a national trend, state health officials announced. Oregon reported 14 pregnancies per every 1,000 girls ages 10 to 17 in 2000, or a total of 2,653, three years after Gov. John Kitzhaber started a statewide program to combat teenage pregnancy. The state surpassed its goal, set in 1997, of 15 pregnancies for every 1,000 girls for last year. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Teenage Pregnancy Rate Drops

docs.lead_paragraph: Pregnancy tests taken too soon after conception may incorrectly tell a woman she is not pregnant, researchers are reporting. In a study of 136 women who had conceived and had a test on the first day they missed a menstrual period, 10 percent got a false negative result. ''Women with a negative test result may fail to protect themselves from exposures to toxicants in the workplace or to medications that could damage a developing embryo,'' said Dr. Allen Wilcox of the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences, writing in the Journal of the American Medical Association.

headline.main: National Briefing | Science And Health: When The Rabbit Lies

docs.lead_paragraph: Jorge Morron was supposed to become a United States citizen on Sept. 17. To record the event, he wanted his pregnant wife, Sonia, to bring a video camera to the swearing-in ceremony, at the Immigration and Naturalization Service bureau in Garden City, N.Y. The two were going to celebrate that evening with dinner at a restaurant. He asked Mrs. Morron to wear her most beautiful clothing. ''The ceremony will be in your honor and our baby's honor,'' she recalled his saying.
docs.abstract: Colombian immigrant eager for American citizenship was among victims of World Trade Center attack; his pregnant widow is being helped by Children's Aid Society, one of 10 local charities supported by The New York Times 9/11 Neediest Fund (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The title of Doug Wright's mischievous and theatrically savvy evening of vignettes, ''Unwrap Your Candy,'' comes from the pre-curtain announcement, ubiquitous now at productions from the Fringe Festival to Broadway. You know: the one that wags a pre-emptive finger at those who would neglect to silence a cellphone or dare to liberate a peppermint. It's a crafty way to send the message that the show, which opened yesterday at the Vineyard Theater, intends to address the theatergoing enterprise and the odd position we put ourselves in. Buy a ticket and you are, after all, at the mercy of people who may as easily pander as entertain you.

headline.main: Inspiration From Hitchcock, Serling and Cellophane

docs.abstract: Bruce Weber reviews four vignettes written and directed by Doug Wright, presented by Vineyard Theater as Unwrap Your Candy; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I am a retired radiation oncologist. As you can imagine, my patients needed all the help they could get, so I asked an orthodox rabbi whether he would participate in a trial like the one in ''A Study Links Prayer and Pregnancy'' (Oct. 2). He said he would not, nor did he believe God would participate. He could not imagine God weighing his mail, pro and con, like a member of Congress. DR. DANIEL OCHS Demarest, N.J.
docs.abstract: Dr Daniel Ochs letter on Oct 2 article cites refusal of orthodox rabbi to participate in trial of efficacy of prayers by strangers; drawing
